LGTM other than the one import issue
Wondering whether we want to include extras in the filtering. It's annoying, and I don't think that there is any secret stuff in there for existing connections. Thoughts?
Note: installed locally, and this did appear to work.

Actually, I take that back. It worked for the hooks. For variables, it only works for very specific fields:

```
    test    test    
    password    ********    
    secret_password test    
```

I would have expected either all to be encrypted, or anything with 'password'/'secret' in it.

@mistercrunch thanks. There is one operational regression (also heads up @aoen, @jlowin, @artwr) due to the eager creation of task instances. In its current form the scheduler will evaluate all State.NONE task instances and thus due to eager creation it will take more time to evaluate them. 

I'm addressing this issue in a follow up PR (almost done/ready for review).

@mattuuh7, this is looking good.
1. Can you remove extras from being masked? I think the cons outweigh the pros of masking it. (I know this is annoying, considering how much time you spent trying to figure out how to mask it. Sorry. :()
2. Can you rename hide_encrypted_ui_fields to hide_sensitive_variable_fields?
3. Could you add some docs either to the .rst or to the config comments saying which variables get masked (password, secret, etc).
4. Could you squash your commit, and rename both the commit message and title of the PR as: 'AIRFLOW-45: Support Hidden Airflow Variables'

This patch is not perfect, but it makes all subcommands which are not related to celery work if the config file doesn't have the [celery] section.

Before applying this:

```
(env)sekikn@ubuntu-trusty:~/dev/incubator-airflow$ grep celery ~/airflow/airflow.cfg 
(env)sekikn@ubuntu-trusty:~/dev/incubator-airflow$ for i in resetdb render variables pause version initdb test unpause run list_tasks backfill list_dags webserver scheduler task_state trigger_dag clear upgradedb; do echo $i; airflow $i; done
resetdb
[2016-05-22 16:57:25,357] {configuration.py:508} WARNING - section/key [celery/broker_url] not found in config
[2016-05-22 16:57:25,358] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor
[2016-05-22 16:57:25,471] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
[2016-05-22 16:57:25,504] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
[2016-05-22 16:57:25,804] {configuration.py:508} WARNING - section/key [celery/celeryd_concurrency] not found in config
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/sekikn/.virtualenvs/env/bin/airflow", line 6, in <module>
    exec(compile(open(__file__).read(), __file__, 'exec'))
  File "/home/sekikn/dev/incubator-airflow/airflow/bin/airflow", line 5, in <module>
    from airflow.bin.cli import CLIFactory
  File "/home/sekikn/dev/incubator-airflow/airflow/bin/cli.py", line 620, in <module>
    class CLIFactory(object):
  File "/home/sekikn/dev/incubator-airflow/airflow/bin/cli.py", line 815, in CLIFactory
    default=conf.get('celery', 'celeryd_concurrency')),
  File "/home/sekikn/dev/incubator-airflow/airflow/configuration.py", line 675, in get
    return conf.get(section, key, **kwargs)
  File "/home/sekikn/dev/incubator-airflow/airflow/configuration.py", line 512, in get
    "in config".format(**locals()))
airflow.configuration.AirflowConfigException: section/key [celery/celeryd_concurrency] not found in config

(all subcommands fail in the same way)

upgradedb
[2016-05-22 16:57:44,137] {configuration.py:508} WARNING - section/key [celery/broker_url] not found in config
[2016-05-22 16:57:44,138] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor
[2016-05-22 16:57:44,249] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
```

@mreid-moz

Thanks for the change and welcome to the project. We do like first commits from newbies to improve documentation so keep them coming. Also, please read our [Contributor Guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributor+Guide), if you haven't done so already. For most PRs, we prefer to have JIRAs pointing to PRs. This change is small enough that it might not matter, but it's a good practice, since we will start measuring project velocity using JIRA.

@jeffreypicard Thanks for taking this on. I had planned at some point to work on this, and as often happens, got swamped. 

I've spoken to a few different companies that use `trigger_dag` and `TriggerDagRunOperator` and one common use-case is to handle high-volume event traffic. One company has thousands of Kafka consumers, each of which run a Sensing DAG that has a custom Kafka sensor. When an event arrives, each Sensing DAG executes a TriggerDagRunOperator which will result in work being done via the processing dag (e.g. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/airflow-lesson-1-triggerdagrunoperator-siddharth-anand?trk=prof-post).

Hence, the cli is one part of the Trigger DAG use-case, the other being the TriggerDagRunOperator.

Hence, to make this work correctly, it seems that you should also ensure the TriggerDagRunOperator is passed an execution date. The one area I might be concerned about, mostly out of ignorance, is whether there will be any unique index violations because of some expectation of granularity of time.

Finally, I had created 2 examples dags in `example_trigger_target_dag.py` and `example_trigger_controller_dag.py`. Feel free to add to those examples. Also, I don't recall if I added tests.. that might be good to add for your new functionality.
@r39132 Thanks for the comments! I'll update the TriggerDagRunOperator and look into your other concerns.
LGTM

Have updated the existing PR to include a `BaseOperator` parameter of `render_params=False` and tested as appropriate in `get_template_context()`. Still trying to work out whether the natural home of this should be `render_templates()` or `get_template_context()`.

For context sake, here is an example operator from one of my DAGs. The `config` and `steps` params are long YAML files which define our EMR clusters and most of these are very similar hence the need to parameterise. Some of the values passed in via the parameters are dynamic and created from other TaskInstances.

``` python
create_cluster = EmrSensor(
    config='resources/emr/cluster/config.yaml',
    steps='resources/emr/steps/steps.yaml',
    params={
        'db_host': "{{ task_instance.xcom_pull(task_ids='create_db') }}",
        'year': "{{ (execution_date - macros.timedelta(days=18)).year }}",
        'month': "{{ (execution_date - macros.timedelta(days=18)).month }}"
    },
    task_id='create_cluster',
    dag=dag,
)
```

So if implemented in  `render_templates()`` are you thinking of something like this (not tested as yet)...?

``` python
    def render_templates(self):
        task = self.task
        jinja_context = self.get_template_context()
        if hasattr(self, 'task') and hasattr(self.task, 'dag'):
            if self.task.dag.user_defined_macros:
                jinja_context.update(
                    self.task.dag.user_defined_macros)

        rt = self.task.render_template  # shortcut to method
        if self.render_params:
            jinja_context['params'] = rt('params', jinja_context['params'], jinja_context)

        for attr in task.__class__.template_fields:
            content = getattr(task, attr)
            if content:
                rendered_content = rt(attr, content, jinja_context)
                setattr(task, attr, rendered_content)

```

I guess it comes down to whether you view that the rendered params are special cases of normal templated variables or whether they are actually now the context for rendering - this was my original view, but after writing out what I think the updated render_templates would look like, it's a little more six of one and half a dozen of the other now. I'm happy to resubmit the PR in whichever form seems best...

NB: It seems that `get_template_context()` is already being called twice during the execution of `TaskInstance.run()`. If there is a worry about performance of the templating then perhaps we should make `render_templates()` accept an optional context to avoid the double call, something like...

``` python
        if not mark_success:
            context = self.get_template_context()

            task_copy = copy.copy(task)
            self.task = task_copy

            def signal_handler(signum, frame):
                '''Setting kill signal handler'''
                logging.error("Killing subprocess")
                task_copy.on_kill()
                raise AirflowException("Task received SIGTERM signal")
            signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, signal_handler)

            self.render_templates(context=context)

    ...

    def render_templates(self, context=None):
        task = self.task
        jinja_context = context or self.get_template_context()
```

When running this off of master, I get:

```
  File "/Users/chrisr/Code/airflow/airflow/www/views.py", line 2038, in hidden_field_formatter
    return getattr(model, name)
  File "build/bdist.macosx-10.10-intel/egg/sqlalchemy/orm/attributes.py", line 293, in __get__
    return self.descriptor.__get__(instance, owner)
  File "/Users/chrisr/Code/airflow/airflow/models.py", line 3200, in get_val
    "Can't decrypt _val, configuration is missing")
AirflowException: Can't decrypt _val, configuration is missing
```

This can be reproduced by going to a fresh airflow install, running `airflow initdb`, `airflow webserver`, and opening the variables UI.

Removing `val` from:

```
column_list = ('key', 'val', 'is_encrypted',)
```

Made the exception go away. The patch appears to work without it, but `val` isn't shown in the table view anymore.
I've determined the issue was with some rows that somehow persisted even after I ran `airflow initdb`. Running `airflow resetdb` fixed the issue.

Ready to merge. Could you change the commit message to:

AIRFLOW-45: Support Hidden Airflow Variables
LGTM as well
